ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a basic understanding of stats and how it applies to political science
I developed a solid foundation for my statistical knowledge and thinking.

I developed skills in time management due to the incredibly flexible options in approaching the asynchronous course. I had a lot of flexibility in when and how I would absorb the material.  Furthermore, I recommend this to students who prefer to do things at their own pace (for me, this was not as beneficial due to putting off watching lectures). It is a good course for learning basic statistics and for students that took AP Statistics is a nice refresher that also introduces concepts of ANOVA.
A lot of introductory statistic terms and using minitab

This course allowed me to learn how to calculate the probability, conduct hypothesis tests, and many different techniques and strategies. I am able to use the information and skills I learned from this class and transform it into in asset that I can apply to the real world.
basic statistics that are the foundation for more advanced stats classes
Learned so much about statistics, much that is useful to real life problems and experiences
I learned the basics of all the core statistics concepts including distribution types, data relationships, experimental design, probability, confidence intervals, hypothesis tests, and regression.
Some basic understanding of the different kinds of statistical methods I could use to model certain relationships.
very basic statistics knowledge
stats
This course was able to give me a better insight on how to apply stats into the real world and was about to cover a lot of the basics.
Basic understanding of stats concepts and some applications, using MINITab. It's a very PSET-based course.
I learned how to use the Minitab software and many basic statistic principles.
I now have a basic understanding of statistical methods, how to apply them, and when each one should be applied.
I learned introductory level Statistics, and completed a requirement for the Political Science major. I also achieved a quantitative reasoning credit.
l learned basic statistics and how to use minitab.
Minitab, Statistics, and R

In this course, I gained a comprehensive understanding of various hypothesis testing methods and received an in-depth overview of regression analysis. The class served as a substantial introduction to the wide-ranging field of statistics, providing me with valuable insights and knowledge in the application of statistical techniques.
I learned the basics of statistics, in terms of what it is meant to achieve and what it can be used for. I also learned about the various techniques that it does use to achieve its goals.

I learned more about ANOVA and ANCOVA, plus I revamped my previous AP Statistics knowledge.  I also learned about Bayesian Statistics (woof) and how to apply good statistical methods to the data I see today, especially misleading graphs in the news.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I love that it can be taken go at your own pace because of the modules and they are a great way to learn difficult material.
plenty of office hours offered to get your questions answered and/or help on p-sets
Love that it can be taken asynchronously.

Strengths: optional asynchronous format worked very well for me 
Weakness: TFs were usually not super helpful in explaining topics, course can also become unengaging

Strengths: 
Instructor is excellent
Asynchronous option and flexibility in exam times make the course very accessible. 

Weakness: 
Would have potentially benefitted from a more clear/consistent formatting of the slides (just in heading/subheading/etc.) so that it is easier to follow along in notes and know how each sub-topic relates to the larger topics discussed.

Strengths: super flexible in the amount of time I would spend on the course, had great example questions, a pretty silly professor 

Weaknesses: I think certain assignments could be worded better to better understand what is being asked for, and a few teaching aides would reschedule office hours last minute.

A lot of office hours. I loved the asynchronous format to learn the way we can learn best. And being able to rewind in lecture videos and rewatch them. Towards the end of the first half of the term, no one was replying to Ed discussion anymore and I was unable to challenge my grades. The other weakness is psets are vague in details. So missing any component of an answer is deduction in grading.

Strengths: ASYNC, a lot of office hours to find answers to your questions, organized
Weakness: TA's were sometimes unreliable as one will say an answer was correct and the other will say the opposite
A weakness is that it is very easy to fall behind due to the virtual options. A strength is that there is a lot of help available and the professor was very engaging.

The main strength of this course is its organization. Professor Reuning-Scherer was very structured and posted all of his materials on Canvas, which was very helpful. I wish the grading for this course was a little bit more transparent, especially on the homework. I felt like I sometimes lost points for things I did not understand. I also wish we had the opportunity to do more group work in this class.

Weaknesses: 
- Although the course was advertised on Course Search as a stats course specifically on political science, almost all examples throughout the entire course had nothing to do with political science. Course Search said that the course would include "problems presented with reference to a wide array of examples: public opinion, campaign finance, racially motivated crime, and public policy," but the examples ended up revolving around concentrations of water or minerals, animals, and other STEM related topics. I understand that the methods are technically the same regardless of subject matter, but I found it very frustrating and unengaging to keep working with material that is not relevant at all to my interests or future academic work. 
- Many of the TAs were not particularly helpful or successful in explaining concepts of the course, but rather resorted to giving out problem set answers. 

Strengths: the remote option allowed for flexible learning.

strengths: if you want to put little effort into a class and get a QR credit, this is a good choice. JDRS's home videos at the end of his lectures was a major highlight. weaknesses: the political science section had nothing to do with political science. Our data sets were still about roaches and manatee boat deaths, etc. This made it a lot less interesting
Jonathan is a good lecturer, no practice problems for exams

I think the strength of this course is how flexible it is with the students. Having the options to go in person or watch the livestream is really helpful and gives you no excuses to not go do the class. The amount of office hours available is also extremely helpful as you can always find a time to attend and join office hours. Having the test online also really helps as someone who gets really anxious and stressed to take tests in person.
The weakness of this course is connected to the strength and that is that it's so easy to fall into the trap of catching up with lecture later and falling really behind. So I recommend to go to class every day if you can. In addition, I think the PSETs can be a bit more connected to the exam so we can be better prepared for them.

Strengths it's really helpful how many resources the course has including recorded lectures and videos, as well as the several office hours each week. I took stats in high school a few years ago, and it was a helpful refresher to have all the different materials. I can't think of any particular weaknesses.
The many options for office hours were a strength of the course.

The course covers a breadth of information, but there is a large amount of deeper learning that the student has to do on their own for full comprehension of the material. Since problem sets are assigned weekly, office hours are more about answering homework questions than digesting the volume of new material.

I found this course to be challenging. The workload was high, and it was difficult to find help through office hours (which were mostly virtual). There was an error in the grading of one of my exams, and it was very difficult to resolve. I know other classmates faced similar challenges with regrade requests or missing grades.

The structure of the course was pretty straightforward, but I took the political science section and we didn't do anything related to polisci. It was just a standard stats class, and I wish there were more datasets actually related to political science.
Asynchronous is a tempting option many students will take, but once you start getting behind it wont stop. As stated in the syllabus, you have to stay on top of it.
I found the flexiblility of the course very helpful. I think it could be improved with more time between pset deadlines. It felt like a lot of work for each week.
The asynchronous unit was extremely well developed and very helpful.
Really approachable and available Professors and TAs.

While the asynchronous option enhances the accessibility of this course, it is important to acknowledge its inherent challenges. The difficulty lies not only in the complexity of the content, making it inherently demanding, but also in the rigorous nature of the tests. Despite the availability of office hours to excel in assignments, navigating the challenging assessments requires a dedicated effort and thorough understanding of the course material. Also the course didn't have much support before the test.

I would say there is a good amount of support because office hours are always there and there is someone to help you. The content is delivered in a way that is easily accessible to everyone, which makes it very easy to understand. The only real weakness is the lack of practice exams given before finals or midterms because there is a disconnect between what the problem sets look like and what the exams themselves look like.

I think the strengths of the course lie in the knowledge and humor of the professor.  He was really engaging in his lectures and came up with different ways for us to remember certain statistics concepts.  I think a weakness is the strengths of the TFs who, in my experience, did not always explain things very well or were reluctant to help to the extent needed.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes
yes, it's a good QR that can also cross-list with many major requirements
Yes, would highly recommend.
If you need statistics, yes. If you are looking for a QR, possibly, but there may be easier QRs.
Yes, especially if never taken stats before. It is very useful and important to be statistically literate.
I would recommend this course to another student because it is very well organized, and the content is approachable through both watching the videos, attending lectures, or simply viewing the slides.
Would recommend

Yes and no, this really depends on the type of student. The class does move very fast as the professor will warn you on the first day of class, however, if you are someone who adapts informations quickly then take the course b/c it was fun and it's async so the class is very flexible. If you're a student who really wants the professor to slow down and explain some parts of the topic more in depth then it's a bit difficult as this class is big and the professor may take weeks to reply to your request through email (better to go in-person to ask questions).

Yes, it's good to have a foundation in statistics and this course is very efficient at teaching the basics. But you do actually have to internalize the material, which can be difficult, so it's not a gut or a QR to be taken unless you truly do want to know some stats.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student interested in learning the basics of statistics. It was a very helpful introduction to many important concepts that can be further explored in more advanced classes.

Unfortunately not. The course did not approach teaching statistics in a very systemic way; for instance, we were only shown a map of the various statistical methods, which helped categorize what we were learning and doing, in one of the last lectures. Before then, we were learning various methods without much clarity on what each of them would or would not achieve. If you already have a solid background in stats and are willing to learn a lot on your own, the course is probably doable. But if you are looking for a QR with more structure and guidance, I would recommend other courses!
sure if you're a STEM person

I would recommend this course to other students. You have all of the tools to be able to get good grades on your PSET and pass the overall class. If you are looking to fulfill your QR credits, this is a good course to do that. But be aware that it is a lot of content.
Yes, it's a good QR! Stats is helpful knowledge to have and there are a lot of resources to guide you along the way.
Yes, I think you learn a lot of helpful statistic principles that could be helpful for many fields.

Since this course is often a prerequisite for majors, I believe the class should be recommended for that sake. Otherwise, the course itself is minimally engaging intellectually and requires a large amount of work for less return on knowledge. The teaching fellows were very kind and helpful, but the course itself fell flat in many ways.
If they also must take this course to complete a requirement, I guess so.
Yes, if you have already taken AP stats. If not, it can be a little fast paced.
I would recommend this course to another student because it was a helpful introductory course to statistics.
Yes, learning basic statistics is a very valuable skill to have.
Yes. Really structured learning with plenty of resources to succeed.
I would yes if they have a strong background in stats.
Yes because it is an easy way to learn the basics of statistics and see if you're interested in it. The professor makes the class enjoyable and there is a lot of support for this class.

Yes, I would recommend this course because it is very adaptable to the schedule of the student and JDRS is an easy person to learn from.  There is an extensive amount of help pathways if needed, but the course information is really interesting and a good basic introductory for people hoping to get into statistics.
